Award.AwardTitle: Empirical Research - Collaborative Research - A Bayesian Approach to Number Reasoning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ultimate goal of this project is to provide a novel model of the cognitive and neural basis of numerical cognition, and to use this knowledge to guide the development of new training methods that could improve mathematical abilities in children. The project is a collaboration among investigators at the University of Rochester, Johns Hopkins University, and Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories. Recent research suggests that acuity of numerosity judgments is predictive of success in formal mathematics education, and that similar cognitive processes can be trained by specific kinds of domain-general experience. The core idea is that the firing of neurons encodes a probability distribution, thereby representing simultaneously the most probable sample from the distribution and the variance (i.e., confidence) of the estimate.

This project will develop and test a formal Bayesian model that has the unique feature of naturally accounting for a number of metacognitive factors, a critical but undertested factor in the acquisition of expertise. The primary advantages of this Bayesian approach are its ability to provide a natural description of: 1) how the confidence of a learner relates to the precision of their number knowledge; 2) how a learner can combine information from multiple sources of information about number; 3) how intuitive preferences (also known as prior belief) predict learners' errors; and 4) how improvements in probabilistic inference may benefit the precision of the number sense.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do we represent numbers? This question is fundamental to our understanding of how the human brain can perform complex mathematical reasoning.  Recent discovery has revealed that we have two ways of representing numbers: a symbolic one which we use when performing formal mathematics, and an analog one which we share with most animals. The analog one allows us to estimate numerosity, like the number of people in a room, in less than a blink of an eye, but only approximately. Studies have shown that our ability to perceive and manipulate these analog representations is the best predictor of mathematical abilities of young children in the class room. Up until recently, this representation was thought to be quite simple: when we see a set of objects, our brain supposedly represents just our current guess about numerosity. Our research reveals that this is not the case. Adult and children alike represent a probability distribution over numerosity. In other words, we can not only represent numerosity but also our certainty around that numerosity. This is fundamental change because this suggests that when we perform addition with analog numbers, or any other type of manipulation, we can track the uncertainty at all stages of the computation. The uncertainty can then be used to guide further decisions. For instance, when picking blueberries, it would seems that it is always best to pick from bushes with the highest estimate of blueberry but this not always true. If the choice is between a bush with few blueberries but high certainty and a bush with lots of blueberry but extremely low certainty (because of the presence of grass obstructing the view of the blueberries), it might make more sense to pick the bush with fewer blueberries.

                Our work also offers promising candidates for how these probabilistic representations are implemented in neural circuits. Since the representation of analog number best predict the ability to perform more formal symbolic mathematics, it might be the case that the probabilistic representation also play a role in symbolic mathematics as well. As the mathematician Laplace proposed more than two centuries ago, it might be that all mathematical reasonings first involve an analog probabilistic stage before it is turned into a rigorous logical reasoning. This certainly fits our own intuition about how our brain derive new mathematical results but further research will be required to resolve this question.
